title: China Report Links State-Secrets Allegations Against Two Canadians
summary: Chinese government-run newspaper says Michael Spavor shared photos and videos of military equipment with compatriot in cases central to China-Canada ties. Two Canadians imprisoned in China on espionage charges are linked by photos of unspecified military equipment one took and shared with the other, according to a government-run newspaper in China that appeared to make public new information about prosecutions that have rattled relations with Ottawa.

title: Use of Antiparasitic Drug Ivermectin Against Covid-19 Prompts Health Warnings
summary: Prescriptions for ivermectin have surged; FDA and CDC cite reports of severe illness resulting from misuse of the drug. Federal health regulators are warning doctors and veterinarians against the unauthorized use of the drug ivermectin to treat Covid-19, as prescriptions of the antiparasitic drug have surged in recent weeks.

title: Texas Abortion Law Takes Effect Pending Supreme Court Action
summary: Justices haven't acted on request by abortion providers to block the state's so-called fetal-heartbeat law. WASHINGTON-A new Texas abortion law that bars the procedure after about six weeks of pregnancy took effect Wednesday, after the Supreme Court didn't act on an emergency request by clinics and abortion-rights advocates to block it.

title: There's No Mystery in Florida's Covid Reporting
summary: Media eager to target Gov. Ron DeSantis have a problem with the switch to a methodology many other states use.. The media has hammered Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis in recent weeks for his handling of Covid as hospitalizations in the state have surged. Fair enough.

title: Eastern Airlines Pivots to Cargo With Plans for Boeing 777 Freighters
summary: The niche passenger airline says it plans to convert used Boeing wide-body jets to take advantage of booming air cargo demand. A small U.S. airline said it has amassed a big fleet of Boeing Co. 777 jets that it plans to convert to freighters, targeting the rapid growth in e-commerce-driven shipping.

title: Purdue Bankruptcy Is Approved, Shielding Sackler Family
summary: Judge approves settlement between OxyContin maker and its owners that will shield the family from opioid lawsuits. OxyContin maker Purdue Pharma LP won court approval of a $4.5 billion bankruptcy settlement that shields its owners, members of the Sackler family, from lawsuits accusing them of contributing to the nation's opioid epidemic in exchange for providing funding to combat the crisis.

title: The Democratic Norm Breakers
summary: The Jan. 6 committee wants to subpoena GOP phone records.. Critics feared that Speaker Nancy Pelosi's probe of the Jan. 6 Capitol riot would be partisan, and the latest proof are subpoenas for the private phone records of House Republicans. This is a violation of political norms that Democrats will come to regret.

title: What's Really in the Texas Voting Law
summary: Progressives are crying 'voter suppression,' but here are the facts.. The Democrats who fled Texas in July to block their Legislature's voting bill eventually had to go home. On Tuesday the bill passed, and Gov. Greg Abbott says he'll sign it. Cue the shouts of "voter suppression," as Democrats push H.R.4, Congress's latest plan to federalize U.S. elections.

title: Texas Abortion Providers Rush to Adjust as New Law Takes Effect
summary: Clinics were squeezing in patients until minutes before midnight ahead of a ban on abortions after six weeks of pregnancy. Abortion providers across Texas are scrambling to adapt to a new law that took effect Wednesday, banning the procedure after about six weeks of pregnancy, the most restrictive abortion law in the U.S.

title: The Entitlement State's Bankruptcy Dates
summary: Medicare is going broke, but Democrats want to add more benefits.. We interrupt the campaign to pass new entitlements with news that the existing programs will soon go broke. That's the word from the annual Social Security and Medicare Trustees reports released Tuesday.

title: SEC Sues BitConnect and Founder, Alleging Massive Cryptocurrency Scam
summary: Regulators take action against company that banked on fervor for cryptocurrencies in $2 billion fraud case. WASHINGTON-Regulators on Wednesday sued an offshore company that allegedly conducted one of the biggest scams ever involving cryptocurrencies.

title: Why Your Beer Costs More
summary: Aluminum prices soar as Biden keeps Trump's 10% tariff.. Perhaps you've heard inflation is increasing amid "supply-chain problems." Translation: Demand for goods exceeds businesses' ability to provide them. But you can also blame the prices of your six-pack of beer in part on bad trade policy.

title: 'O. Henry: 101 Stories' Review: A Twist Comes at the End
summary: William Sidney Porter, writing under his famous pen name, relied on deadpan humor, a feel for the lives of ordinary people-and astonishing finales.. Before he was known as O. Henry and the author of "The Gift of the Magi," William Sidney Porter wrote another yarn about a husband and wife who miscommunicate. Instead of trading Christmas presents in a touching tale of self-sacrifice, they exchange "some hard words" over breakfast. A little later, they regret their remarks and seek to make peace. When they meet again, however, they fire off a new round of accusations-painful to them in their fictional world but amusing to readers who recognize a comic mixture of spite and affection in a marriage.

title: Most of New Orleans Still Lacks Power, Running Water
summary: Resume Subscription. NEW ORLEANS-Lines were long, tempers were short and the heat was stifling Wednesday as the recovery from Hurricane Ida logged its third day.

title: Biden's Ugly Defense of His Afghan Failure
summary: His lie-loaded speech caps off a debacle that could sink his party in 2022 and 2024.. Joseph R. Biden Jr.'s surrender in Afghanistan and the chaotic, inept and shameful way he effected the capitulation have left an indelible stain on his presidency. The distortions he used Tuesday to justify his actions compounded his historical blunder.

title: A Tax Plan to Destroy Farms and Ranches
summary: When owners die, their heirs depend on the step-up basis for capital gains.. During my service as a U.S. senator and ambassador to China, I was honored to represent the interests of America's family farmers and ranchers. As part of a four-generation ranch family myself, I understand how these businesses help feed America and the unique challenges they face.

title: Can Congress Tax Wealth by 'Deeming' It Income?
summary: A challenge to a 2017 law could shut the door to Elizabeth Warren's far more ambitious levy.. Charles and Kathleen Moore have done well, but they certainly aren't billionaires. Yet the couple's constitutional challenge stands to slam shut the door on a federal wealth tax like the one Sen. Elizabeth Warren wants to enact.

title: TIAA Names Dave Dowrich as Chief Financial Officer
summary: The appointment comes as new CEO Thasunda Brown Duckett puts executive leadership team in place. Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association of America named a new chief financial officer as the retirement services and investment firm reshuffles its leadership team.

title: 'Forever Young' Review: The Fantasy World of a Disney Girl
summary: At 14, she was getting over 7,000 fan letters a week, all addressed, she thought, to a 'Hayley Mills' much prettier and wittier than she was.. Talented child performers, from Baby Peggy in the silent era to Emma Watson in the "Harry Potter" films, have long enjoyed a special relationship with moviegoers. One of the most captivating of these precocious luminaries was Hayley Mills, who starred in half a dozen Walt Disney films starting with "Pollyanna" (1960) and "The Parent Trap" (1961).

title: Why Hurricane Ida Wasn't Katrina
summary: The low death toll in Louisiana this week is a revealing but cautionary American success story.. The news cycle has become a hurricane, blowing away reality every 24 hours. Before Hurricane Ida, it was Kabul. Before Kabul it was the earthquake in Haiti, which occurred less than three weeks ago but got pushed aside despite more than 2,000 deaths. Before Haiti it was the million-migrant crisis on the southern border, said to be caused in part by two hurricanes that devastated Central America last year. The Biden White House hopes memories of Kabul will also blow away soon.

title: Taliban Battle Opposition Militias, Wield New Power in Kabul
summary: Resume Subscription. Clashes flared in northern and central Afghanistan between the Taliban and local militias on Wednesday, as the Islamist movement continued to consolidate its grip on power in the Afghan capital two days after the U.S. ended its 20-year presence in the country.

title: What to Know About the Purdue Settlement
summary: The OxyContin maker won approval of a chapter 11 reorganization plan that will end civil lawsuits against the Sacklers and turn the drugmaker into a public benefit company addressing the opioid crisis. OxyContin maker Purdue Pharma LP won court approval of a multibillion restructuring plan that will turn the drugmaker into a new public benefit company that will use its resources to address the opioid epidemic and compensate people and families harmed by its products.

title: West Virginia Governor Settles With Bank Over Soured Business Loans
summary: Governor, his family have struggled with alleged defaults on business loans they personally guaranteed. West Virginia Gov. Jim Justice has come to an agreement with his longtime bank lender that will quash existing lawsuits they filed against each other over alleged defaults by some businesses owned by his family, according to the family and other people familiar with the matter.

title: Elijah McClain's Police-Custody Death Leads to Five Indictments
summary: Five current, former first responders face charges in Black man's 2019 Colorado death following new investigation. title: GameStop's S&P 500 Return in Hands of Anonymous Panel
summary: Members of panel have considerable discretion over which companies to include in the most widely watched equity index. The individual-investor darling GameStop Corp. is now three times as valuable as the smallest S&P 500 stocks, thanks to a sharp run-up in its shares in August.

summary: S&P 500 has climbed for nine of the past 10 months and sits near its all-time record. The Nasdaq Composite jumped to a record to start the month, building on its strong gains from August.

summary: The newly designed display at the American Museum of Natural History is as eye-catching as it is educational..

summary: Wednesday's meeting took place against backdrop of Kyiv's opposition to Russian natural-gas pipeline. President Biden and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky met on Wednesday to discuss the countries' bilateral relations and Ukraine's tensions with Russia and aspirations to join the West, addressing a simmering foreign policy challenge for Mr. Biden in the wake of the U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan.

title: Two Trump Organization Employees Are Set to Testify
summary: Senior finance official and director of security set to appear this week as criminal probe into Donald Trump's business affairs continues. Two Trump Organization employees are expected to testify before a grand jury this week as Manhattan prosecutors seek to advance their criminal investigation into former President Donald Trump's business affairs, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: An Embarrassing End to War in Afghanistan
summary: We will need to send our military back to retrieve American citizens.. Allowing the Taliban to dictate terms in such a way that we were not allowed to remove all our citizens and allied Afghans is reprehensible, irresponsible and plain stupid ("Biden's Rush to the Afghan Exits," Review & Outlook, Aug. 25). This debacle falls squarely on President Biden's shoulders, and his poor decision-making has exacerbated an already bad situation. There is little doubt that we will need to send our military back into Afghanistan to retrieve our people, and that this will cost lives.

title: Who's Really Not Paying Their 'Fair Share'?
summary: About 61% of American households-more than 100 million of them-paid no federal income tax last year.. Regarding your editorial "Bernie Sanders Runs Out of Billionaires" (Aug. 31): Have we forgotten that only a few years ago, the Vermont senator's goal was to run out of millionaires? But as luck would have it, his book sales and his salary put him in the millionaire class, so now he focuses on chastising billionaires for not paying their fair share. Hypocrisy is so much a part of those who live the subsidized life in Washington.

title: Texas Voting Bill Will Make It Harder to Vote
summary: S.B.1 empowers partisan poll watchers to intimidate voters and election workers while increasing voting barriers.. Karl Rove's op-ed "Democrats Will Soon Play Texas Fold 'Em" (Aug. 19) claims my filibuster of Texas' voter-suppression bill "focused on two elements of the measure": prohibitions on drive-through and 24-hour voting. In fact, I spent over 13 hours of my 15-hour filibuster detailing provisions in the bill, known as S.B.1, that empower partisan poll watchers to intimidate voters and election workers while increasing voting barriers for seniors, persons with disabilities and minorities.

title: OPEC Alliance Keeps Gradual Output Increases, Despite U.S. Request
summary: OPEC, group of Russian producers resist U.S. call to ramp up output faster. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and a group of Russia-led producers said they agreed to continue increasing oil production in measured steps, resisting for now recent U.S. pressure to open the group's spigots wider.

title: McConnell Urges GOP Voters to Focus on Midterms, Not Biden Impeachment
summary: Senate Republican leader says narrow Democratic control of House and Senate makes push against president impractical. title: Medicare Advantage and the Incentive to Minimize Patient Care
summary: The more tests, procedures and hospital stays that are performed, the less profit for the sponsoring group.. Regarding Dr. Nathan Punwani's letter "Medicare Advantage Shows the Path Forward" (Aug. 30): Medicare Advantage is a capitation program. That means that for every enrollee, the program receives a fixed amount of money. The more tests, procedures and hospital stays that are performed, the less profit for the sponsoring group, be it an insurance company or a Medicare Advantage group. Cost risk is passed onto the sponsor of the plan.

title: Pelosi Prefers to Play Politics on the Eviction Ban
summary: Meanwhile, the government has failed to distribute rental-assistance money.. While the Supreme Court correctly deemed President Biden's extension of the ban on evictions illegal ("Justice Kavanaugh Replies to Mr. Biden," Review & Outlook, Aug. 28), Speaker Nancy Pelosi cynically denounced the decision as cruel and immoral. What is really cruel is that only a fraction of the nearly $47 billion that Congress allocated for the Emergency Rental Assistance Program has been distributed. The speaker should not inject herself into the court's decision for political gain, but rather see to it that landlords are paid so tenants can remain in their homes.

title: Majority of Interpreters, Other U.S. Visa Applicants Left Behind in Afghanistan
summary: U.S. still doesn't have reliable data on who was evacuated from Afghanistan, a senior State Department official says. WASHINGTON-The U.S. estimates it left behind the majority of Afghan interpreters and others who applied for visas to flee Afghanistan, a senior State Department official said on Wednesday, despite frantic efforts to evacuate those at risk of Taliban retribution.

title: Organ Loft (Thursday Crossword, September 2)
How to Test a Relationship: An Arduous Hike Through the Himalayas
summary: A trek in India to the glacial source of the Ganges River, writes Jai Chakrabarti, helped him and his girlfriend decide whether to spend their lives together. LIVING IN NEW YORK, amid all the suffering the pandemic has brought here and abroad, I keep returning to a trip I took to the Himalayas. Fifteen years ago I hiked to the glacial source of the Ganges River, otherwise known as Gaumukh or "the cow's mouth." In this moment, that memory becomes refuge.

title: Does Russia Even Want to Collude With Biden?
summary: Putin and his cartel reject a White House request.. Despite very favorable policies from the White House, Russian President Vladimir Putin still doesn't feel like doing U.S. President Joe Biden a solid. Readers will recall the bizarre episode last month when Mr. Biden, who is pushing expensive taxpayer-funded policies to reduce oil production, suddenly urged Russia and its allies in the international energy cartel to increase oil production. The news then was that Mr. Biden didn't believe in forecasts of climate doom enough to run the political risk of high gasoline prices. The news now is that cartel members don't seem that eager to collude with him. Maybe the petro-states figure they can get what they want without giving anything in return.

title: Joshua Kushner and Karlie Kloss In Contract for Puck Penthouse
summary: Resume Subscription. Venture capitalist Joshua Kushner and supermodel Karlie Kloss are in contract to buy a sprawling New York City penthouse developed by his family's real-estate empire, according to people familiar with the transaction.

title: What to Watch: Six New Movies and Shows to Stream This Week

Pop star Camila Cabello teams up with "Pitch Perfect" director Kay Cannon for a modern take on "Cinderella." And "Will & Grace" star Sean Hayes plays a gay James Bond. Here's where to stream it all.

title: 5 Interior Design Ideas for Inexpensive Art-From Wall Rugs to Framed Memories
summary: Does your budget preclude original paintings? Interior design pros share low-cost alternatives they hang to bring beauty and meaning to walls.. TURNS OUT you can improve the way you feel by lazily staring at nicely decorated walls. "Incorporating art and color into your home design will have a positive impact on your mood and overall health," said Jessica Shaw of New York's Turett Collaborative architecture and design firm, citing studies from the American Association for the Advancement of Science. And the nerve-calming wall installation doesn't have to be a 19th-century Arcadian masterpiece. It can be baskets, even an array of hats. "It's authenticity that counts," Ms. Shaw said. "What is that thing for you? What gives you a hit of dopamine or serotonin? If a collection of old Levi's is a genuine reflection of you, go ahead and frame them." Other substitutes for pricey artwork: a group of trip mementos, a public-domain photograph that reflects your obsession with katydids. Here, design pros offer their favorite low-cost alternatives to an Alice Neel original.

title: U.S. Spies Didn't Cause Kabul to Fall
summary: The Biden administration apparently wants to make a scapegoat out of the intelligence community.. Biden administration officials may try to blame the U.S. intelligence community for the Afghanistan debacle. The New York Times on Aug. 18 cited an unidentified senior administration official, who claimed that as the situation grew more volatile in July, U.S. intelligence agencies never offered a clear "high confidence" prediction of an imminent Taliban takeover. But the role of intelligence in critical national security decisions is to reduce uncertainty, not to provide perfect clarity.

title: Congress Needs to Rein In a Too-Powerful Federal Reserve
summary: The Fed's unchecked power has led to measures favoring those who live off portfolios, not paychecks.. When Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell speaks, investors listen. They listen as if there are fortunes to be made by guessing correctly about when the Fed might begin cutting back on the amount of U.S. government-backed debt it buys every month. They listen for the stray word that could spook financial markets. Mr. Powell's speech on Aug. 27 proved to be unspectacular in all the ways that count on Wall Street. Nevertheless, it was a spectacle.

The styles of these videos range from silly and creative to straightforward and professional. Here are three things you should know about the rise of video résumés.

summary: After seven years in the condo, the death of her husband and a long pandemic lockdown, the homeowner wanted an upbeat change. Seven years later, the homeowner-whose husband died 18 months after they moved in-was spending a lot of time indoors because of the pandemic.

title: This Quick Trick Makes Steamed Mussels Sensational
summary: A garlicky, herby compound butter comes together fast and brings remarkable oomph to the mussels' vermouth-based broth. THOUGH THE MENU at Fore Street in Portland, Maine, changes constantly according to what's in season, best and freshest, it's a good bet you'll always find mussels there. "They grow just a few miles away, on Casco Bay," said the restaurant's French-born chef, Frédéric Eliot. "I'm sure other French people will argue with me, but these are, hands down, the best I've ever had, big and sweet."

title: Bryce Harper May Be the Most Hyped-and Underrated-Player in Baseball
summary: Harper has been usurped in the public eye by younger stars. But he's having an MVP year that could lead the Phillies to the playoffs.. It isn't a stretch to call Bryce Harper the most hyped player in baseball history.

title: Designer Virgil Abloh: 'I've Been Tapped With a Magic Wand'
summary: The artistic director of Louis Vuitton's menswear and CEO of Off-White discusses his historic rise to the top of the industry, opening the door for a new generation of fashion and the cherished ideas and objects he's collected along the way.. From his early years as "a skater kid who loved graphic tees," as he puts it, to becoming the artistic director of menswear at Louis Vuitton in 2018, Virgil Abloh has arrived at a place in the fashion world no Black man has ever been. Born to Ghanaian immigrants outside of Chicago, Abloh, 40, never entered the industry expecting to fit in. The name of his multifaceted, Milan-based label, Off-White, launched in 2013, implies as much: It's not black or white; it's both. It's casual sweatshirts with a $1,000 price tag. It's an homage to hip-hop within an institution that had long undervalued the genre's cultural relevance. Now that he's sold a majority stake in his brand to Louis Vuitton's parent company, LVMH Möet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, subsequently taking on greater responsibilities across the French conglomerate, Abloh has cemented his status as one of the most powerful people in fashion-and is well-positioned to continue reimagining luxury from the inside out.

title: Why "I'll Just Suck It Up" Doesn't Work
summary: WSJ. asks six luminaries to weigh in on a single topic. This month: Endurance.. Kristin Chenoweth

title: Definitely Not Your Grandma's Sweater
summary: Fall's newest knits make for forward-thinking ensembles, with bright colors, fuzzy textures and crocheted patterns to heat up cold-weather style.. Say farewell to a wardrobe of wispy cotton dresses and light-as-a-feather linen separates-it's time to embrace the crisp autumn air with cozy layers. There are fresh and exuberant takes on warm woven pieces in all shapes, sizes, prints and fabrics for head-to-toe styling. In a new twist on crocheted granny squares, Miu Miu is offering a matching coat, sweater and headpiece, and Marni has a top and matching pants in striped stitches. A fuzzy pink cardigan with matching pants from Acne Studios and Chloé's striped dress and matching oversize bag bring bright color to overcast days.

title: Southwestern Style and Korean Moon Jars: The Best-Designed Items of September
summary: Louis Vuitton's birthday bling, the best boho bags and more editors' picks this month.. Louis Vuitton 's new high jewelry Bravery collection pays tribute to the brand's eponymous founder on his 200th birthday with 90 unique pieces designed by Francesca Amfitheatrof, artistic director of jewelry and watches. The Le Mythe necklace, shown here with the Le Mythe bracelet, is composed of thousands of specially cut stones, including sugarloaf-cut sapphires and diamonds arranged in the brand's signature Damier pattern. It's a nod to the checkerboard design that first appeared on Louis Vuitton's canvas luggage in 1888. -Jill Newman

title: The Gorgeous Milan Apartment Shared by Two Design Stars
summary: Architects Fanny Bauer Grung and David Lopez Quincoces's 1920s apartment is equal parts design lab and family home.. The issue with running a design gallery, according to architect Fanny Bauer Grung, is eventually having to part with the furniture. "This chair has been the source of problems," she says, pointing to a simple wooden seat with angular armrests and a woven back. A flea-market find, it now sits next to the white marble fireplace in the Milan apartment that Bauer Grung, 32, shares with fellow architect David Lopez Quincoces, 41, her partner in life and work. The chair used to be on display in the couple's design space, Six Gallery, where it caught the eye of a client. It wasn't for sale, though, and the client left the gallery nearly in tears. "It's a piece that is so dear to me," Bauer Grung says, "so it had to come home."

title: Chinese Liquor Giant to Get a New Chairman
summary: Proposed handover comes months after regulators rebuked current boss. The top job at China's most valuable domestically listed company, Kweichow Moutai Co. , is set to change hands after less than two years.

title: For Labor Day Travel, Keep Up With Covid-19 Mandates
summary: Whether you are traveling domestically or internationally, plan ahead for the long weekend, as the Delta variant spreads. A hectic season of summer travel has been complicated by rising cases of the Delta variant of Covid-19.

title: Refineries Potentially Face Weekslong Outages
summary: Storm leaves fuel makers in Louisiana struggling to restart after damage to power grid. Refineries that were caught in the path of Hurricane Ida could take weeks to resume operations because of widespread power outages.

title: Surging Covid-19 Cases Hammer Asian Factories
summary: Continuing struggles in region's manufacturing sector could lead to higher prices for consumer goods such as shoes and electronics. HONG KONG-Factory activity faltered across Asia in August, with a resurgence in Covid-19 infections adding to global supply-chain disruptions and confirming fears of a slowdown in the region's economic recovery.

title: Vietnamese-Americans Organize to Aid Afghan Refugees
summary: People who arrived in the U.S. after the Vietnam War see similarities in the plight of Afghans today. Vietnamese-Americans who came to the U.S. as refugees more than 40 years ago and their children are mobilizing to help Afghans with whom they feel a kinship at the chaotic end of another lengthy war in Asia.

title: A Devastating Hurricane Has Left the New Orleans Saints Homeless. Again.
summary: The Saints are preparing to be away from New Orleans for the first month of the season. The team will play its home opener in Jacksonville.. Hurricane Ida unleashed untold devastation in Louisiana, where the immense rain and wind damage has left schools closed, residents without power and hospitals relying on generators. It has also created an uncertain future for one small group of evacuees: the New Orleans Saints.

title: Evergrande's Grand Finale Won't Be Pretty for Investors
summary: Beijing has good reasons to ensure that apartment buyers don't get stiffed, but investors might be less lucky. China's most indebted property developer needs to sell more apartments to survive, but it also needs to find the cash to build them. In the end, some of that cash will likely come from the government-but that doesn't mean the company will survive in its current form, or that bondholders will emerge unscathed.

title: North Korea Rejects Covid-19 Vaccine Doses
summary: Pyongyang says Sinovac shots offered through the Covax initiative should be sent to other countries instead. SEOUL-North Korea has turned down roughly three million doses of Covid-19 vaccines developed by Chinese drugmaker Sinovac Biotech Ltd., instructing that they should instead be sent to harder-hit countries.

title: Travel Agencies Are Having a Moment Amid Covid Chaos
summary: A business that lost ground to do-it-yourself online travel booking is back with the added complications of cancellations, border restrictions and testing requirements. Zoom, ring lights, stationary bikes and food delivery. To the list of products and services that found new life because of the pandemic, you can add travel advisers.

title: USA Gymnastics Proposes $425 Million Settlement With Larry Nassar Victims
summary: The offer has been backed by a committee of survivors, but it's not clear where the money would come from. USA Gymnastics is proposing a payment of $425 million to settle claims by the victims of the former national team doctor Larry Nassar, including some of gymnastics' biggest stars, the embattled sports governing body said in a court filing late Tuesday.

title: Hurricane Ida Leaves Residents Without Power Amid Punishing Heat
summary: Louisiana schools are closed, hospitals operating on generators with power outages expected to last up to a month. NEW ORLEANS-The winds and rain from Hurricane Ida have passed, but the devastation wreaked by the storm weighs on every aspect of life here.

title: In Leaving Afghanistan, U.S. Reshuffles Global Power Relations
summary: Resume Subscription. After Afghanistan's U.S.-backed government collapsed on Aug. 15, Beijing couldn't contain its glee at what it described as the humiliation of its main global rival-even though Washington said a big reason for withdrawal was its decision to focus more resources on China.

title: Energy Traders See Big Money in Carbon-Emissions Markets
summary: Vitol, Glencore and other firms that dominate oil trading are beefing up their carbon-trading desks. LONDON-Big energy trading houses, long focused on deep, volatile markets such as oil and natural gas, are now bulking up their carbon-trading operations as governments around the world push to expand the market for trading carbon emissions.

title: Europe's Banks Get a Cash Boost From ECB Credit Moves
summary: Region's lenders are booking higher revenue from a central-bank program to support the economy. The European Central Bank wants to make sure credit is flowing into Europe's economy to support its recovery as the pandemic drags on. Banks are cashing in.

title: Cities Add Emergency Facilities for Mental Health
summary: Resume Subscription. Emergency facilities dedicated to mental-health patients are sprouting up across the U.S. to handle psychological trauma exacerbated by the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Clothing Retailers Boost Profit Margins by Offering Fewer Markdowns
summary: CFOs say they're focused on keeping inventory levels lean to avoid end-of-season price cuts. Clothing retailers are improving their profit margins by keeping their inventory low and offering fewer end-of-season markdowns, after being stuck early on in the pandemic with apparel they struggled to sell.

title: States That Cut Benefits Saw Limited Impact on Jobs
summary: Half of U.S. states ended enhanced unemployment insurance payments early ahead of nationwide termination of benefits for millions of people. States that ended enhanced federal unemployment benefits early have so far seen about the same job growth as states that continued offering the pandemic-related extra aid, according to a Wall Street Journal analysis and economists.

title: China's Curbs on Videogames, Celebrity Fandom Seek to Make Kids Tougher
summary: Measures also target for-profit education. SINGAPORE-Under President Xi Jinping, China's Communist Party has moved to aggressively reassert control over the economy, going after some of the country's largest private enterprises in a drive to dial back what it sees as the capitalist excesses of a previous era.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Canadian National Voting Trust for Kansas City Southern Deal Denied by Regulator
summary: Surface Transportation Board says Canadian National hasn't demonstrated that use of voting trust would be consistent with public interest. Canadian National Railway Co. 's $30 billion bid to buy Kansas City Southern ran into a major obstacle Tuesday, with regulators ruling the Canadian railroad won't be permitted to complete a deal using a temporary voting trust that was a crucial part of the offer.
